When a current \( I_1 \) passes through the rod, the springs do not stretch, indicating that the magnetic field is not exerting any force on the rod.
The springs not stretching implies that the magnetic force on the rod is balanced by the tension in the springs.

The tension in the springs is given by \( T = k \times \Delta x \), where \( \Delta x \) is the elongation of the springs.
When the current direction changes, the magnetic force on the rod will change direction and will no longer be zero.
Since the magnetic force is opposite in direction to the tension in the springs, the elongation of the springs will increase when the current direction changes from \( b \) to \( a \).
The elongation \( \Delta x \) of the springs is given by \( \Delta x = \frac{T}{k} \), where \( T \) is the tension in the springs and \( k \) is the spring constant.

Since the elongation \( \Delta x \) is directly proportional to the change in magnetic force, the elongation will increase by the same amount when the current direction changes from \( b \) to \( a \).
